text:
Hmmm... I wonder what platforms do people use Julia on
   :windows95:, :apple: or  :linux: ？

elements.text: Hmmm... I wonder what platforms do people use Julia on
or

text: see <https://julialang.org/assets/2020-julia-user-developer-survey.pdf>

elements.text: see

text:
I find it hard to believe that the numbers don't add to 100, for choice of OS....
Which means, someone uses Julia on multiple OS, which is kinda rare....

elements.text:
I find it hard to believe that the numbers don't add to 100, for choice of OS....

text:
<@U680THK2S> You're a rare person:rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:
How'd your describe your freebsd experience compared to whatever you used before？:slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: You're a rare person
How'd your describe your freebsd experience compared to whatever you used before？

text:
> Which means, someone uses Julia on multiple OS, which is kinda rare
Actually, I don't think it's all that rare. I run Julia on Linux (desktop and AWS EC2 for work), macOS (laptop), and FreeBSD (anywhere I can install it). I think at least the combination of work OS and personal OS is likely fairly common.

elements.text: Which means, someone uses Julia on multiple OS, which is kinda rare

Actually, I don't think it's all that rare. I run Julia on Linux (desktop and AWS EC2 for work), macOS (laptop), and FreeBSD (anywhere I can install it). I think at least the combination of work OS and personal OS is likely fairly common.

I don't understand why someone would use Julia in Windows with Linux (unless forced by their workplce to do so)

text:
I don't know about how stuff works in the industry, but I hear that employees are forced to work on a specific OS in some companies
The very thought annoys and scares me:slightly_frowning_face:

elements.text:
I don't know about how stuff works in the industry, but I hear that employees are forced to work on a specific OS in some companies

text: I see people all the time using Windows and Linux with whatever software they use. Usually at my university most PhD students just use windows in their personal computers because that is their preference but if they want to run something in a computing cluster they inevitably have to use linux. I am in a similar situation but macOs and Linux in my case.

elements.text: I see people all the time using Windows and Linux with whatever software they use. Usually at my university most PhD students just use windows in their personal computers because that is their preference but if they want to run something in a computing cluster they inevitably have to use linux. I am in a similar situation but macOs and Linux in my case.

text: Oh yeah, I guess I also use Julia on Linux on the cluster but didn’t even think to click the Linux button at first.

elements.text: Oh yeah, I guess I also use Julia on Linux on the cluster but didn’t even think to click the Linux button at first.

text:
It'll take time for me to understand why'd someone keep a bloaty and clunky OS as Windows, as their personal preference
Like, any Windows user here would like to tell why they prefer Windows over other options?

elements.text:
It'll take time for me to understand why'd someone keep a bloaty and clunky OS as Windows, as their personal preference
Like, any Windows user here would like to tell why they prefer Windows over other options?

text: A coworker of mine switched from Linux to Windows for his personal computer because he could run Linux software in WSL and just about everything else in Windows. I know a common theme for people who run Windows is that they want to be able to run games.

elements.text: A coworker of mine switched from Linux to Windows for his personal computer because he could run Linux software in WSL and just about everything else in Windows. I know a common theme for people who run Windows is that they want to be able to run games.

text: honestly at this point, I haven't had a game recently not work on linux (thanks to Wine/Proton). I know not everything works perfectly, but at least for what I play, I've had no complaints

elements.text: honestly at this point, I haven't had a game recently not work on linux (thanks to Wine/Proton). I know not everything works perfectly, but at least for what I play, I've had no complaints
I know a common theme for people who run Windows is that they want to be able to run games.
What games run on Windows that don't run on Linux? Isn't supertuxkart enough?!?

text:
> It’ll take time for me to understand why’d >someone keep a bloaty and clunky OS as >Windows, as their personal preference
I’ve been using linux since middle school, I like it a lot but I can understand why people would like to have windows. I don’t know if basic things like installing a printer or having up to date drivers for their graphic cards will ever be a thing in linux. Many things suck about windows but not everything.

elements.text: It’ll take time for me to understand why’d >someone keep a bloaty and clunky OS as >Windows, as their personal preference

I’ve been using linux since middle school, I like it a lot but I can understand why people would like to have windows. I don’t know if basic things like installing a printer or having up to date drivers for their graphic cards will ever be a thing in linux. Many things suck about windows but not everything.

text: Also: Windows is _far_ better than it used to be.  The old tropes aren’t really applicable anymore.

elements.text: Also: Windows is
far
better than it used to be.  The old tropes aren’t really applicable anymore.

text: it still requires restarts for way too many things and phones home a ton. Also there have been about 3 different file corruption update problems in the past 4 years.

elements.text: it still requires restarts for way too many things and phones home a ton. Also there have been about 3 different file corruption update problems in the past 4 years.

text: Windows is quite slow when it comes to file operations as well

elements.text: Windows is quite slow when it comes to file operations as well

text: We got SSDs, which improved things a lot for Windows, so now it is actually usable. But it's still slower than Linux

elements.text: We got SSDs, which improved things a lot for Windows, so now it is actually usable. But it's still slower than Linux

text: Windows really needs a modern file system. NTFS hasn't recieved a major upgrade in 2 decades

elements.text: Windows really needs a modern file system. NTFS hasn't recieved a major upgrade in 2 decades

text:
<@U01AJUF2GEP>, I use Windows (I also have PC's in home with Linux Mint and macOS Catalina) because I find it the better OS than Linux / macOS. Linux feels faster on IO operations. But the whole UI / UX experience of Windows 10 with the flexibility of Windows is just a better choice from my PoV.
While Windows 10 comes indeed with more services than a Linux OS, speed wise, if you look at the latest comparisons between Linux and Windows it is not a slow OS by any means.

elements.text:

While Windows 10 comes indeed with more services than a Linux OS, speed wise, if you look at the latest comparisons between Linux and Windows it is not a slow OS by any means.

text:
I had to use Windows for my previous job. It was not a good experience, but that may in part be because of all the corporate software run on it.

Still, WSL and Cygwin were much worse than my experiences with terminals in Linux or Mac.

text: I changed to KDE some Ubuntu versions ago because both Ubuntu default desktop and Gnome crashed before starting with nvidia drivers at the time (even with an empty $HOME). It's not integrated as well to Ubuntu as the others, but it always worked well enough for me

text: The mystery of Windows slowing down. I've always been a Windows person. I rarely reboot my computer. Never noticed any slow down. Everything I need runs _well_ on Windows. I've used WSL2 when I needed to run Linux-only software and had no problems (though, granted, that isn't often and wide use). And yes, perhaps most games run on Linux, but if they still run better on Windows, why put up with it?

text:
The only reasons why Windows is relevant, for me, would be
1. It comes installed by default (biggest reason)
2. It has _more_ games (for now)
3. It has _less_ options, and only system updates! (Fedora Silverblue gives you that too, but I guess not many know about it)

text:
> The mystery of Windows slowing down. I've always been a Windows person. I rarely reboot my computer. Never noticed any slow down.
I agree. My system is 3 years old and runs like new. In Windows it is easy to find "Portable" applications so the system is untouched for years.
Both Intel and AMD have applications (Windows only as far as I know) for Real Time Overclocking with application awareness (When I launch Julia / MATLAB, it overclocks the CPU).
Hardware support is easier and again, the Linux performance advantage is almost gone beside IO.
I get why people would chose differently. As both macOS and Linux are decent. But Windows is more than a decent OS. So I don't get why would someone think it is not a legit choice.
By the way, for developers I find Windows much better if you're after C / C++ / C#. No IDE on earth come close to Visual Studio for those.

elements.text: The mystery of Windows slowing down. I've always been a Windows person. I rarely reboot my computer. Never noticed any slow down.

Hardware support is easier and again, the Linux performance advantage is almost gone beside IO.
I get why people would chose differently. As both macOS and Linux are decent. But Windows is more than a decent OS. So I don't get why would someone think it is not a legit choice.
By the way, for developers I find Windows much better if you're after C / C++ / C#. No IDE on earth come close to Visual Studio for those.

text:
> Hardware support is easier and again, the Linux performance advantage is almost gone beside IO.
Really? A lot of my devices don't work in Windows versions newer than XP. My mother's Windows 8 laptop came with a wifi chip not supported by Windows 10 (and after every Windows 10 update, it uninstalls the drivers automatically). In Linux though? It all works...
